qas.question: What is the term used for veneration of Mary in Roman Catholic theology?
In what year was the hierarchy of latria, hyperdulia and dulia established?
Who is venerated in the Roman Catholic practice of dulia?
Which theologian wrote that Mary is considered to be "superior to all created beings," but is not to be the object of worhip?
What is the Roman Catholic term used to denote the worship of God?
When did the the Second Council of Nicaea begin?
When did the the Second Council of Nicaea end?
What is the Ortodox term used to denote the worship of God?
What is the Ortodox term reserved for Marian veneration?
In what year did Sergei Bulgakov attend the Second Council of Nicaea?

context: Although the Catholics and the Orthodox may honor and venerate Mary, they do not view her as divine, nor do they worship her. Roman Catholics view Mary as subordinate to Christ, but uniquely so, in that she is seen as above all other creatures. Similarly Theologian <a3_0>Sergei Bulgakov<a3_0/> wrote that the Orthodox view Mary as "superior to all created beings" and "ceaselessly pray for her intercession". However, she is not considered a "substitute for the One Mediator" who is Christ. "Let Mary be in honor, but let worship be given to the Lord", he wrote. Similarly, Catholics do not worship Mary as a divine being, but rather "hyper-venerate" her. In Roman Catholic theology, the term <a0_0><b8_0>hyperdulia<b8_0/><a0_0/> is reserved for Marian veneration, <a4_0><b7_0>latria<b7_0/><a4_0/> for the worship of God, and dulia for the veneration of <a2_0>other saints and angels<a2_0/>. The definition of the three level hierarchy of latria, hyperdulia and dulia goes back to the Second Council of Nicaea in <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0><b9_0>787<b9_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>.
